---

Hi [FIRST_NAME],

You've got your construction budget approved. The contractor's bid looks reasonable. You're ready to move forward.

Then the "extras" start appearing.

I've seen this derail too many projects. Here are the 5 costs that almost everyone forgets to budget for:

**1. SITE WORK SURPRISES ($40K-$150K)**
‚Ä¢ Soil conditions different than expected
‚Ä¢ Rock excavation
‚Ä¢ Underground utilities in wrong location
‚Ä¢ Stormwater management requirements

‚Üí SOLUTION: Invest $8K-$15K in geotechnical study BEFORE you finalize design

**2. PERMIT FEES & IMPACT FEES ($15K-$80K)**
‚Ä¢ Building permits (obvious)
‚Ä¢ Impact fees for roads, schools, utilities (not obvious)
‚Ä¢ Plan review fees
‚Ä¢ Inspection fees

‚Üí SOLUTION: Call the building department early - get fee schedule in writing

**3. UTILITY CONNECTION COSTS ($30K-$200K)**
‚Ä¢ Bringing power to the site
‚Ä¢ Water/sewer tap fees
‚Ä¢ Gas line extensions
‚Ä¢ Telecom infrastructure

‚Üí SOLUTION: Contact utility companies 6+ months ahead - some have 12-month lead times

**4. FURNITURE, FIXTURES & EQUIPMENT ($25-$75/SF)**
‚Ä¢ Office furniture
‚Ä¢ Warehouse racking
‚Ä¢ Specialized equipment installation
‚Ä¢ Technology infrastructure

‚Üí SOLUTION: Budget this separately from construction - it's often 15-20% of building cost

**5. SOFT COSTS DURING CONSTRUCTION ($$$)**
‚Ä¢ Continued rent at current location
‚Ä¢ Construction loan interest
‚Ä¢ Insurance during construction
‚Ä¢ Project management time (your time has value)

‚Üí SOLUTION: Create a month-by-month cash flow projection including ALL costs

**THE BOTTOM LINE:**

If your contractor quotes $2M for construction, your all-in cost is likely $2.4M-$2.6M.

Plan for it now, or scramble for cash later.

‚úì You're risk-averse (can't absorb 20% cost overrun)

‚úì Timeline is flexible
